headline: 'I regret leaving Man Utd after they paid record transfer fee - but I liked it at Man City'
body: Andy Cole regrets leaving Manchester United when he did(Image: Clive Mason /Allsport)

Andy Cole admits he regrets leaving Manchester United when he did because he'd have won more trophies - but enjoyed his time playing for Man City. The rivals face off in the Manchester derby on Saturday, and Cole knows exactly what it is like in each dressing room ahead of the clash.

Cole spent almost seven seasons at Old Trafford and won nine major honours, including the Treble. He joined United from Newcastle for a British transfer record fee at the time, signing for £6million with £1m-rated Keith Gillespie going the other way.
But he left in 2002 for even more money to join Blackburn Rovers and eventually ended up at Manchester City in 2005. Speaking after his retirement, Cole admitted he departed the Red Devils too early.
He said: "[Sir Alex] told me that I didn't have to go, he didn't want me to go. I could have stayed for as long as I could and I would get my games.

"In the end, he just said, 'Okay, I understand, and I know what you are like, I will let you go'. The crazy thing is that he sold me for £7million, which is more than what he paid for me – he got me for £6m.

"So I remember that last meeting with him like it was yesterday. I really enjoyed my time, but I left far too early. That is my only regret. I could have stayed at the football club for a lot longer and, looking back, I wish I had."
Reflecting on missed opportunity, Cole added: "Just because you have won everything, that doesn't mean you don't want to win it again.

"If I was what I am now – more relaxed and calculated in what I want to do – I would have thought about it and realised I would have played games and still be involved in 20 to 25 games a season and win a hell of a lot more, but it wasn't to be."
Cole enjoyed his best years at Old Trafford(Image: Richard Sellers/Sportsphoto/Allstar via Getty Images)

Cole made the leap from one side of the city after a stint at Fulham, saying it was a "great honour" to play for both Manchester clubs. Speaking to the Independent before a derby in 2005, he said: "The fact I had played for United and had such a good time there was on my mind when I considered City's offer, I cannot lie.

"When you've been at a club for so long and you have achieved so much with that club, I mean I achieved things at United that I never believed I would, then you close it and move on and end up at their rivals then of course it crosses your mind.
"But I am a professional footballer, simple as that. I had a great time at United, but that came to an end, and now this is a new chapter.
Cole enjoyed his time in sky blue(Image: PAUL BARKER/AFP via Getty Images)

"Personally, I consider it an honour to have played for both clubs in my career. Some Manchester United fans might not see it that way and some Manchester City fans might not see it that way but it really is an honour for me to have played for two great clubs."
Highlighting the other stars who made the unthinkable jump between rivals, Cole added: "A lot has been made about me coming here and you would think I am the only player ever to have made the switch.

"Denis Law did it, Brian Kidd did it, and a lot of people seem to forget that both Shaun Goater and Jon Macken played for United early in their careers, but because I had so much success with United and was there for the most successful period in the club's history people seem a lot more apprehensive about my move."

headline: 'I've worked with Man Utd boss Michael Carrick recently – this is what impressed me'
body: Michael Carrick is preparing his side for the Manchester derby(Image: Manchester United via Getty Images)

Gabby Logan has lavished praise on Michael Carrick's communication skills after working with him on Match of the Day. Carrick has stepped in as Manchester United's interim boss for the rest of the season following the dismissal of Ruben Amorim.

The ex-United and England midfielder edged out Ole Gunnar Solskjaer for the role and is set to face his first test in a Manchester derby in Saturday's early kick-off. Since departing Middlesbrough last summer, Carrick has dabbled in media work, including a stint on Match of the Day, where Logan shares hosting duties with Mark Chapman and Kelly Cates.

On The Sports Agents podcast, Logan expressed her admiration for Carrick's game insight and his knack for conveying his observations succinctly. This skill could prove invaluable as he seeks to make an immediate impact on the underperforming United squad.
First, Chapman, a United supporter, quipped: "How bad company must we be for him to say, 'I'll go and try my hand with this shower."
Logan added: "We've both worked with Michael Carrick this season and he's gone off to manage one of the biggest basketcases in the world!"

On a serious note, Logan added: "In all seriousness, we were both really impressed with him, how brilliantly he was able to read the game and then incisively put it into a minute or two of analysis, which is a real skill. He just read the game brilliantly and beautifully. It feels like he's a master tactician."

Chapman suggested that Carrick will need to step up as a motivator, as United aim to salvage their season by securing a spot in the Champions League. He said: "He will also need to be a phenomenal motivator because of the state they're in because they've got no other football now, bar league games.
Gabby Logan was impressed with Carrick on Match of the Day(Image: The Sports Agents)

"The last time they were in this situation, it was with Ralf Rangnick, and the whole thing spiraled out of control very quickly. It was quite acrimonious and miserable, so he's got a lot of work to do on that front."

Carrick hopes his efforts will secure him the job permanently in the summer. However, Oliver Glasner could pose a challenge, having announced he will leave Crystal Palace when his contract expires in June.

Speaking ahead of the derby, Carrick said: "I know what it takes to succeed here. My focus is now on helping the players to reach the standards that we expect at this incredible club, which we know that this group is more than capable of producing.
Carrick has undertaken punitry work since leaving Middlesbrough(Image: Manchester United via Getty Images)

"I have worked with a number of the players already and have obviously continued to watch the team closely in recent years. I have total belief in their talents, dedication and ability to be successful here.
"There is still a lot to fight for this season, we are ready to pull everyone together and give the fans the performances that their loyal support deserves."

headline: Man Utd's response to Oliver Glasner bombshell emerges in latest job twist
body: Oliver Glasner had been linked with Manchester United before confirming he will leave Crystal Palace this summer(Image: Alex Livesey - Danehouse/Getty Images)
Oliver Glasner may be leaving Crystal Palace at the end of the season but the Austrian's availability will not necessarily bolster his chances of landing the Manchester United job.

Glasner, 51, has made a seismic impact at Selhurst Park since taking the reins two years ago. His stock rose significantly when he guided the south London outfit to glory in the FA Cup last season - their first major trophy - and he has been consistently linked with more high-profile jobs in recent months.

With his contract expiring at the end of the season, Glasner has most recently been touted as a top contender to succeed Ruben Amorim when United hire a new permanent head coach in the summer, and the former Eintracht Frankfurt chief dropped a bombshell on Friday when he confirmed he would NOT be signing a new contract with Palace.

However, The i Paper claim that Glasner is behind Thomas Tuchel and Roberto De Zerbi on United's shortlist - even though he would be available without compensation. Part of the reasoning behind that is Palace's recent poor form, with Glasner overseeing a winless run that spanned nine games.

The report goes on to outline that the powerbrokers at Old Trafford are seeking a head coach with Premier League experience; something Tuchel and De Zerbi both have. The Paris Saint Germain boss, Luis Enrique, has also been mentioned, although there are doubts he would attainable.
England boss Thomas Tuchel is one of the names being eyed for the Manchester United job(Image: Eddie Keogh - The FA/The FA via Getty Images)

While speculation over Glasner's future has been rife for months, he revealed that he had informed players on Friday that he would be leaving in the summer. His announcement coincides with the news that Marc Guehi, the Crystal Palace captain, is on the brink of a transfer to Manchester City.

“I already informed the club months ago that I wanted a new challenge,” Glasner said in a press conference ahead of the weekend. “We had a very long talk, and I told him (chairman Steve Parish) I will not sign a new contract.

“We agreed at the time it was the best to keep it between us. It's the best that we could do that and keep it confidential for three months. But now it's important to have clarity, and we had a very busy schedule so that's why we didn't want to talk about it. Steve and I want the best for Crystal Palace.”

headline: Liverpool aren't the only big losers in Marc Guehi saga as Man City clinch transfer coup
body: Marc Guehi is closing in on a transfer to Manchester City(Image: Julian Finney/Getty Images)

You could probably hear the groans from Merseyside at Crystal Palace's Beckenham training ground when Oliver Glasner confirmed Marc Guehi was Manchester City-bound in an explosive press conference on Friday afternoon.

As much as Crystal Palace fans were rueing the news that their captain and star defender was on the move, Liverpool fans would also have been cursing after seeing their hopes of signing the sought-after Guehi - who came so close to a switch to Anfield back in the final hours of the summer transfer window - dashed for a second and final time.

It was expected that Liverpool would make a fresh play for Guehi, 25, in 2026 given their defensive deficiencies this year, though it soon became clear such a move would not materialise in this window. But Manchester City have now gazumped them to ensure that cannot happen full stop - and it's not just Liverpool who should have regrets.
Because every team at the top of the Premier League should have been on Guehi's tail if he was available this month for the £30million that City seem to have plundered him for.

Liverpool's need for a centre-half - and interest in Guehi - make them a no-brainer when you consider the winners and losers from Friday's big news but City have got one over on half the Premier League, not just Arne Slot's men.
A host of top clubs were courting Guehi ahead of a possible free transfer in the summer(Image: Getty Images)

Arsenal retained a long-term interest in Guehi, although, in truth, they are already rich with quality defenders. But Guehi improves every other one of the Premier League's elite, including his former club, Chelsea.

The Blues might bank a small windfall due to the sell-on clause they included in the deal that took Guehi to Selhurst Park, but he would surely get into Liam Rosenior's team, even though they also boast a significant number of defenders.

The same for Manchester United, who are the latest team to court Nottingham Forest's Murillo. Whether Guehi would have joined United given there are no guarantees of Europe are another matter, but they are at least in with a better chance than last year. And signing a defender of Guehi's ilk would have been a genuine statement.

Palace will see Guehi's exit as a double-edged sword: they lose their one of their most influential figures at a far from ideal time but bank a reasonable sum for a player who had effectively already committed to leaving for free. Do the pros outweigh the cons?
Guehi has become an England regular one of the Premier League's top defenders since leaving Chelsea(Image: )

Wherever you stand on that, Manchester City are the big winners here; they've landed a player whose stock would surely have only gone up after the World Cup, where he is a guaranteed starter for England, for an absolute bargain fee. In contract - and considering he is still yet to hit his prime - Guehi would have commanded a premium price. Maybe close to three times as much as what City will actually pay for his services.

A penny, too, for Mikel Arteta's thoughts. With Liverpool all but out of the title race and Arsenal in a strong position, he's had to watch Manchester City go out and sign two of the Premier League's best players this season in Guehi and Antoine Semenyo.
Even with Arsenal's strength in depth in defence, the Gunners boss will be green with envy. And so should the other managers of the Premier League's elite when it comes to Guehi.

headline: Man Utd transfer news: Red Devils offered ex-Chelsea star as Oliver Glasner makes decision
body: Could Manchester United be looking right at their next manager?(Image: Sebastian Frej/Getty Images)
Manchester United could be on the hunt for players and a new manager this month. The Red Devils have been handed a double boost as Amad and Bryan Mbeumo return to the squad for the derby on Saturday.

Interim boss Michael Carrick will be able to call upon the two attackers following their return from AFCON as he seeks a successful run to the end of the season. United host Manchester City on Saturday afternoon with no new additions to the squad.

In comparison, City have secured Antoine Semenyo from Bournemouth, and he is already firing with two goals in two games so far. City have also just agreed a deal to sign Crystal Palace centre-back Marc Guehi.

Oliver Glasner has confirmed he will leave Crystal Palace at the end of the season following his contract expiration. The FA Cup winner's deal will end in June, and his future in London has been in doubt amid strong links to United.

Glasner said: "I had a meeting in October with Steve Parish. We had dinner and a long talk. I told him I will not sign a new contract for Crystal Palace. We agreed it was best to keep it between us, confidentially, and we did for three months. I told the team today. It’s now important to have clarity.

"I don’t want to have this question. We had a very busy schedule. We want the same, me and Steve. Steve has no ego. Oliver Glasner has no ego, we want is best for Palace. It’s important to have clarity, this is what the players deserve, this is what fans deserve, that’s why I tell it today."
Oliver Glasner confirmed his Crystal Palace exit on Friday(Image: Sebastian Frej/Getty Images)

He added: "I told Steve [Parish] I’m just looking for a new challenge. I told him in October, it’s nothing to do with the transfer window. I hate if something is written or said which is not true, and it was very tough for me not to respond. We have a great relationship, and we’re always talking about what is best for Crystal Palace.
"I haven’t spoken to any other club, I told the players that and promised them today I will give my best to give the best season in Crystal Palace history, the best points tally in history."
Glasner made history with the Eagles by guiding them to an FA Cup win last year. Now, his Palace exit coincidentally lines up with Carrick's future departure from United after taking interim charge.
Ruben Loftus-Cheek could be on his way to Old Trafford(Image: Gabriele Maltinti/Getty Images)

Manchester United are reportedly among several clubs that have been offered Ruben Loftus-Cheek by AC Milan. TeamTalk reports that the Red Devils have the opportunity to secure the former Chelsea midfielder in January.
Milan are said to be open to a loan with an obligation to buy in the summer. Other clubs also in the running include Newcastle, Sunderland, Fulham, Aston Villa, Everton and Brentford.

The 29-year-old left the Blues in 2023 after an eight-year tenure, heading to Italy permanently following loans at Palace and Fulham. Across his career, the midfielder has scored 30 goals and made 32 assists in 367 appearances. Loftus-Cheek won two Premier League titles, one Europa League and the UEFA Super Cup with Chelsea and could be a solid addition to United.

headline: Wantaway Man Utd player 'changes agents' in January transfer hint
body: Manchester United youngster Tyler Fredricson could be on the move this month(Image: James Gill/Danehouse)
Manchester United academy graduate Tyler Fredricson has changed agents midway through the season in a move which could pave the way for a transfer this month, it has been claimed.

Fredricson, 21, is a promising centre-back who has risen through the ranks at United, though he has made just a handful of senior appearances to date, one of which was a start in the unfortunate League Cup defeat at the hands of League Two Grimsby Town back in August.
The young defender has been a regular on the bench for United this season. However, a new report which revealed the identity of his new agent speculates that he could soon be on the move.

The Sun claim that Fredricson's decision to join Murdock Sports Group from the Stellar agency is 'likely' to culminate in a transfer, though it is unclear if that would be in the January window or at the end of the season.

The agency is run by Colin Murdock, the group's founder, who came through the Manchester United academy himself back in the 90s. Former United midfielder Scott McTominay and Jonny Evans, a member of Michael Carrick's new coaching team, are also on Murdock's books, while his son is a goalkeeper in the club's academy.
Murillo has been touted as a summer transfer target for United(Image: Joe Prior/Visionhaus via Getty Images)

Further changes in central defence could be on the cards at the end of the season following reports that United are looking to add a new player to their ranks with Nottingham Forest's Murillo of interest.

The 23-year-old, who joined Forest for just £10million back in 2023, has caught the eye significantly across the last two-and-a-half seasons and has previously been linked with both Chelsea and Liverpool, with The Mail reporting he is now on United's radar.

In terms of outgoings, former club captain Harry Maguire's future remains up in the air with his contract due to expire at the end of June. The same report claimed United were looking at new signings to prepare for Maguire's departure.
The England defender joined United for £80m back in the summer of 2019 in a deal which made him the world's most expensive defender.

headline: Four Man Utd transfer targets as identity of 'mystery midfielder' becomes clearer
body: Michael Carrick could get midfield reinforcements this month(Image: PA)

Manchester United are in a state of flux and rumours are swirling in the January transfer window. Michael Carrick is the new interim head coach until the end of the season, when sweeping changes will be made by the club’s hierarchy.

Ruben Amorim was sacked earlier this month and the club are now plotting a way forward following yet another failed appointment. Carrick is a stop-gap until the summer when a long-term successor to Amorim will be hired and the squad overhauled.

One of the areas of concern is central midfield, where Amorim failed to find the right balance in his 3-4-2-1 formation. There are concerns over the future of captain Bruno Fernandes, while Casemiro is expected to leave on a free transfer when his contract expires.

United are keeping an eye on Brighton’s Carlos Baleba, Nottingham Forest’s Elliot Anderson and Crystal Palace’s Adam Wharton as dream signings in the summer. But they are also weighing up a move this summer, according to reporter Ben Jacobs.

It has been suggested that United have held talks with a ‘mystery midfielder’ in the past day over a possible loan move until the end of the season. The player is understood to be based abroad but has Premier League experience.

The bait has well and truly been taken on social media, where United fans have turned into detectives to try and unmask the player using the parameters given. Here we list four players who fit the criteria.

The overwhelming majority of desperate United fans named the former Wolves midfielder. United were linked with the Portugal international before he left Wolves for Al-Hilal in 2023 and that excitement is back.

Al-Hilal paid a reported £47million for Neves, who was one of the Saudi Pro League’s biggest coups. He is believed to be one of the highest earners in Saudi football, but his contract expires in the summer and is therefore potentially available.

Neves is still only 28 years old, has 171 Premier League appearances, with 21 goals and nine assists, and could have the added advantage of tempting Bruno Fernandes to stay and play with his international team-mate. However, it seems very unlikely that Al-Hilal would accept a loan deal, rather than a straight transfer, having priced him at £20m.
Manchester United are long-term admirers of Ruben Neves(Image: Abdullah Ahmed/Getty Images)

This sounds a lot more likely. Loftus-Cheek is keen for more game time in order to have a shot at making England’s World Cup squad and AC Milan are willing to let him leave, having signed Luka Modric, Adrien Rabiot and Samuele Ricci in the summer.

Loftus-Cheek has reportedly been offered to Aston Villa, after they missed out on Conor Gallagher to Tottenham. The 29-year-old has 10 goals and nine assists in 157 Premier League appearances from his time at Chelsea and loan spells with Fulham and Crystal Palace.
Ruben Loftus-Cheek hasn't been playing regularly for AC Milan(Image: Claudio Villa/AC Milan via Getty Images)

The USA international does have Premier League experience, albeit just 19 appearances from a 2023 loan spell with Leeds United. He has frequently been linked with a move away from Juventus, where he has finally started to nail down a place in the side.

Jacobs reports that McKennie has attracted interest from two Premier League teams, Atletico Madrid and a team in Italy. That is partly because his contract is due to expire in the summer, meaning he could be available for around £10m. He is potentially a not very exciting signing for United, but does tick some boxes.
Weston McKennie has been shopped around recently(Image: Getty Images)

O’Riley is currently on loan with Marseille from Brighton and has been playing for the French club, returning one goal and six assists in 22 appearances in all competitions so far. His departure from the Seagulls in the summer came as something of a surprise after Fabian Hurzeler was unable to guarantee a regular starting role.

The 25-year-old Denmark international has fared better with Marseille, but isn’t a fixture for Roberto De Zerbi either. Nevertheless, it seems very left-field for Brighton to recall him and agree to send O’Riley on loan to a rival in the same league.

headline: 'I know Man Utd's dream January signing very well – he'd make them a better team'
body: Jaap Stam has offered Manchester United some transfer advice(Image: 2025 James Gill - Danehouse)

Manchester United legend Jaap Stam has identified Frenkie De Jong as the perfect signing for the Red Devils. Last summer, United were in the market for a new central midfielder but failed to complete a deal.

Despite Ruben Amorim's departure, strengthening the middle of the park remains high on the club's to-do list, especially with interim boss Michael Carrick expected to switch to a back four formation, requiring an additional midfielder.

The Red Devils have been linked with several targets including Brighton's Carlos Baleba, Crystal Palace's Adam Wharton and Nottingham Forest's Elliot Anderson, but their expensive price tags have so far put the club off making a move.

A major signing in January appears unlikely, with United planning to tackle the midfield situation comprehensively at the end of the campaign. However, Stam has urged his former employers to go after Barcelona star De Jong, branding him a "dream" signing, reports the Daily Star.
"My dream signing for Manchester United in the January transfer window would be Frenkie de Jong from Barcelona," Stam told Covers.com.

"United should always be looking at players who can make them play better football, and Frenkie has been on the club's shortlist ever since Erik ten Hag was in charge. I've worked with Frenkie a lot when he was a youngster at Ajax and he really is someone who can make a team play better football.

"He's so comfortable on the ball and he's got the legs to run up and down the pitch. He's creative and he finds the right passes when he's on the ball, which is something that United need at the moment."
Throughout Erik ten Hag's tenure at United, the club were heavily linked with De Jong, but the Dutch international never made the switch despite financially-stricken Barcelona pushing for his exit.
Frenkie de Jong has been linked with a move to Man Utd for years(Image: Getty Images)
The 28-year-old, who worked with Stam at Ajax, transferred from the Eredivisie club to Barca in 2019 and has clocked up 282 appearances for the Catalan giants in the years since.

However, his spot in the starting line-up was far from secure following a red card against Celta Vigo in November, leading to a near two-month wait before reclaiming his place in the La Liga side's first XI, along with the captain's armband.

Stam suggested that if De Jong proves unattainable, United should reignite their interest in Baleba. "Elsewhere, Carlos Baleba from Brighton is a very good player and he could do well at Old Trafford," he proposed.
Stam reckons De Jong would be perfect for United(Image: Getty Images)
"I'm always looking at the United's system and how I want them to play, and I believe they would become a better team with Baleba and De Jong in there."
Stam spent three years at Old Trafford as a player. He joined the club from PSV in 1998 and played a central role in United's historic Treble-winning campaign.

The defender went on to make 127 appearances for the Red Devils before being sold to Lazio in 2001. Sir Alex Ferguson would later brand his decision to let Stam leave as one of his biggest managerial blunders.

headline: Oliver Glasner's dream Man Utd signing has already given transfer green light
body: Crystal Palace defender Daniel Munoz has already signalled his desire to join a club like Manchester United as speculation grows around Oliver Glasner(Image: Getty Images)

Oliver Glasner may not have to look far for his first Manchester United signing in the event he takes over at Old Trafford this summer. The Austrian sparked fresh speculation of a move to the Theatre of Dreams on Friday by confirming he won't extend his deal at Selhurst Park beyond this summer.

It just so happens that would dovetail nicely with the end of Michael Carrick's interim contract at his old club. The Champions League-winning midfielder has taken the reins until the end of the season but faces a stiff test convincing United's hierarchy to employ him on permanent terms.

Glasner's arrival could fall perfectly for Daniel Munoz. Not only has the Colombia international communicated he would love to join a European superpower like United, but the Red Devils also have need of a player fitting his profile.

That could leave Glasner with a no-brainer decision in the summer transfer window later this year. Speaking to Spanish outlet AS, Munoz confessed he has ambitions of playing for Europe’s biggest clubs, including United. And he went so far as to admit it would be "a dream" to play for a team like United.

"First of all, I think there’s a lot of talk about one club or another,” he said. “If you ask me, it would be a dream to play for one of these clubs, whether it’s Barcelona, PSG, Real Madrid, or Manchester United.
“I think I’m working towards that. I strive every day to one day attract the attention of one of these clubs, because for me, it’s a dream to get there."

Diogo Dalot had been United's right-back of choice but hasn't been the most reliable, in addition to several injury setbacks this season. That saw Carrick's predecessor, Ruben Amorim, promote Amad Diallo to the starting wing-back role in recent months.

Munoz, 29, has been thriving in a similar wing-back capacity for Palace since joining the club from Genk in January 2024. He has three goals and two assists in only 14 Premier League outings this season and was instrumental to the club's FA Cup success last year.

While his age profile isn't ideal, United are in need of assets at the peak of their powers right now. The player has a little more than two years remaining on his contract in south London, however, putting Palace under no immediate pressure to sell.
Glasner may be desperate to keep hold of Munoz and could chase a reunion this summer(Image: Getty Images)

It works in United's favour that the Eagles spent just £6.6million to acquire the full-back from Genk two years ago. That, combined with the fact he turns 30 in May, could help United secure a cost-effective deal, especially if he's enticed by the prospect of reuniting with Glasner.

Given Palace's success under the Austrian in recent seasons, numerous players in south London have seen their valuations rise. United might therefore expect to pay a premium compared to the fee Palace snagged Munoz's signature, but it's unlikely to prove prohibitive.

One intriguing aspect is the fact Glasner often operates with three at the back in defence, a similar system to the one that frustrated many United fans under Amorim. However, in the off-chance he does get the nod to come in as United's next permanent manager, having a straightforward target like Munoz might go a long way.

Manchester United head coach Michael Carrick insists he wasn't fazed by Roy Keane's criticism of his wife and stated he can brush off the views of former colleagues at Old Trafford.

headline: Oliver Glasner announces shock Crystal Palace exit to put Man Utd on red alert
body: Oliver Glasner has confirmed that he will leave Crystal Palace at the end of the season. The Palace manager's current contract expires in June and the Austrian has decided not to sign a new one.

He is understood to be one of the names being considered by Manchester United, who will appoint a new long-term boss in the summer after appointing Michael Carrick as interim head coach until the end of the season.

“I already informed the club months ago that I wanted a new challenge,” Glasner said on Friday in a press conference. "We had a very long talk, and I told him (chairman Steve Parish) I will not sign a new contract.

"We agreed at the time it was the best to keep it between us. It's the best that we could do that and keep it confidential for three months. But now it's important to have clarity, and we had a very busy schedule so that's why we didn't want to talk about it. Steve and I want the best for Crystal Palace."
Glasner joined Palace from Eintracht Frankfurt in February 2024 to replace Roy Hodgson. He helped Palace win the FA Cup last season and has won 41 of his 95 matches in charge.

His final decision comes after he promised to 'intensify' talks with the Palace hierarchy earlier this month. “I think in the next weeks, we will intensify the talks," he said ahead of the FA Cup tie against Macclesfield, which they went on to lose.

"With Macclesfield, Friday again, we go up north, and then everyone gets three days off after Macclesfield and then we have to target four regular weeks and in those weeks we will intensify the talks and I expect to find a final decision.”

Glasner is on United's radar following the sacking of Ruben Amorim earlier this month. The Austrian coach favours the same 3-4-3 tactical system as the fired Amorim and United are on the lookout for a long-term successor after handing the reins to Carrick.

United's hierarchy, led by chief executive Omar Berrada and director of football Jason Wilcox, are leading the search for a new manager. Glasner is among the names they are considering along with Carrick, England boss Thomas Tuchel and ex-Three Lions coach Gareth Southgate.

Speaking last week, Glasner added: “There has been speculation since I arrived. So, believe me, I don't really care about it. I can sign today, or a player can sign a contract extension today and leave in summer. That's why for me, the length of a contract in these times doesn't say anything about your future."

Palace were dumped out of the FA Cup by non-league Macclesfield last weekend and are currently 13th in the Premier League ahead of their trip to Sunderland on Saturday afternoon. They are winless in nine games across all competitions and are also set to lose captain Marc Guehi, who is on the brink of a transfer to Manchester City in the January window.

headline: 'Man Utd manager was sacked as I was about to sign - I declined when I saw the replacement'
body: Former Real Madrid and Germany midfielder Toni Kroos (Image: Getty Images)

German icon Toni Kroos has lifted the lid on how he nearly joined Manchester United - only for the club to give David Moyes the boot whilst negotiations were still underway. Moyes was handpicked as Sir Alex Ferguson's successor at Old Trafford when the Scottish great hung up his boots in 2013.
The former Everton boss found life tough at United and was shown the door after a mere 10 months in the hot seat. But before his departure, the Scotsman was busy trying to strengthen his squad.

Kroos is widely regarded as one of the best midfielders of his era and landing him would have been a massive statement signing for United. The German maestro was just 24 at the time and plying his trade at Bayern Munich.

Reports suggested he was keen on making the switch to the Premier League under Moyes. But Kroos' career path veered dramatically when United made the call to axe Moyes - whilst he was still in discussions with the midfielder.
Speaking to SPORT1, Kroos said: "In 2014, before I signed with Real Madrid, I had already agreed with Manchester United.

"That would have been a move from Bayern to United. But then they kicked out David Moyes, who I was still sitting on my couch with in Munich and hired Louis van Gaal. Then we both declined with thanks."

Kroos opted to sign for Madrid when Carlo Ancelotti was at the helm of Los Blancos. He bagged a host of trophies in Spain, including five Champions Leagues, five Club World Cups, four UEFA Super Cups, four La Liga titles, one Copa del Rey and four Spanish Super Cups.
Toni Kroos could have joined Man United(Image: Sebastian Frej/)
Kroos wasn't the only big-name signing that eluded Moyes. The former West Ham boss also missed out on Gareth Bale and Cesc Fabregas during his tenure at United.

Reflecting on this in 2016, he said: "When I first went in to United my real target was Gareth Bale. I felt all along that Gareth Bale was a Manchester United player and I fought to get him [from Tottenham ] right up until the last minute.
David Moyes was sacked by Man United after just ten months(Image: 2014 Getty Images)
"We actually offered him a bigger deal than Real Madrid but Gareth had his mind made up on going to Madrid. He was, though, in my mind, the player I really wanted.

"The other one I came really close to getting was Cesc Fabregas, who we thought we would get [from Barcelona ] right up until the last minute. And Sir Alex [Ferguson] had told me there was always a chance Cristiano Ronaldo might come back from Real Madrid."

headline: Ruud van Nistelrooy lands new job just days after Old Trafford rejection
body: Ruud van Nistelrooy has landed himself a coaching job in his homeland(Image: PA)
Ruud van Nistelrooy has landed himself a new job just days after being overlooked for the Manchester United job as he joins the Netherlands.

The former Dutch striker, who scored 35 goals in 70 games for his national side, will come in as an assistant from February and work under Ronald Koeman. Van Nistelrooy has been out of work since he was axed by Leicester in the summer following their relegation.

The 49-year-old has previously served as an assistant at Old Trafford and, for a brief period, was the caretaker following the sacking of Erik ten Hag. Van Nistelrooy was then among three men considered for the head coach role until the end of the season.

He and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer were edged out by Michael Carrick with Van Nistelrooy not even meeting the hierarchy, unlike the other two men. He had worked with Manchester bosses last season and they felt they knew what he would bring.

Despite being overlooked Van Nistelrooy has quickly found himself back in a job with the Netherlands bringing him into the fold for a second time, just months out from the World Cup as they bid to win a first major tournament since 1988.

A statement read: "Ruud van Nistelrooy will be part of the Dutch national team's coaching staff from February 1. The former striker will join Ronald Koeman as an assistant coach in preparation of the 2026 FIFA World Cup. Welcome back, Ruud!"

One of Van Nistelrooy's early coaching gigs saw him form part of Louis van Gaal's staff at the 2014 World Cup. He has also enjoyed managerial success in his homeland, taking charge of former club PSV and winning the Dutch Cup during his year at the helm, where he had a 64 percent win rate.
Ruud van Nistelrooy was appointed by Leicester shortly after his spell with Man United, but was dismissed at the end of the season(Image: Getty Images)

The Dutch made the semi-finals of the last major tournament, eventually losing to England in dramatic circumstance in the last four. Koeman has retained his job ahead of the World Cup where the Netherlands will be among the European sides fancying their chances.

They have been drawn in a group with Japan and Tunisia with the fourth team still to be determined by a play-off. Koeman has said: “Maybe we are not considered the big favourite to win it, but we are a team that can surprise everybody.”

headline: Michael Carrick promotes Man Utd youngster to first team on eve of Man City clashVIDEO
body: Michael Carrick has welcomed Habeeb Ogunneye into his training sessions this week after taking over as Manchester United’s interim head coach. Carrick has been preparing his players for the Manchester Derby on Saturday, but hasn’t missed the opportunity to take a look at the club’s academy players.

The former United midfielder was announced as the new boss on Tuesday evening and has a daunting first task against City. He quickly assembled a coaching staff and got to work at Carrington with the players who had been led by Darren Fletcher after Ruben Amorim was sacked.

Carrick is keen to put his own stamp on the side and included Ogunneye, a 20-year-old defender, in sessions. Ogunneye was recently recalled from a loan spell at Newport County and was given a chance to catch the eye by training with the senior squad.

The route from the academy to the first team has been there for all to see recently, with Jack Fletcher and Shea Lacey given game time. However, The Sun reports that the plan is for Ogunneye to be sent out on another loan for the second half of the season.
Michael Carrick has taken over Manchester United training (Image: Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)

He fell down the pecking order at Newport after Dave Hughes – a former United academy coach – was sacked as manager and replaced by Christian Fuchs. The right-back will continue to train at Carrington before another move is lined up.

Nevertheless, his involvement is an example of Carrick’s desire to create an even stronger link between academy and first team, which is shown by the inclusion of Travis Binnion on his coaching staff. Binnion has been promoted from his role as lead coach for United’s under-21s, having also previously worked as the academy's head of player development and coaching.

Carrick was asked to reflect on the recent inclusions of academy players in the first team on the Inside Carrington podcast. "I've absolutely loved it. Everyone needs a chance, you know. Every younger player needs a chance and wants a chance. It's up to them to then earn the opportunity,” he said.
Habeeb Ogunneye has trained with the Manchester United first team this week(Image: Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)

“That's always something I've been passionate about. Even when I was playing, if a younger player comes into the group, into the squad, I would be helping them and trying to guide them and give them advice. Seeing them flourish and almost fly because they've got that feeling they play for the first team and they've got that opportunity to come on the pitch.

“It's what this club has seen for so long and what we are all excited about. It's what the fans want to see, that freshness and rawness and unpredictable talent. So, for me to work with the players, to try to help them and give them opportunities, I'm definitely all for that because that's what this place should be.”

Gary Lineker has playfully predicted that Manchester United will name Michael Carrick as manager, only to give him the boot by December. The former Match of the Day host labelled the club as "bonkers" in light of a tumultuous 18 months.

Ruben Amorim was given his marching orders by United last Monday after a falling out with the club figures. His tenure at Old Trafford came to an abrupt halt just hours after his tirade following their 1-1 stalemate with Leeds United.

Lineker anticipates that Carrick will shine during his temporary stint at the Theatre of Dreams, leading to a full-time appointment. However, he predicts the ex-Middlesbrough boss will be shown the door next season.

headline: Michael Carrick handed blunt Manchester Derby verdict as Man Utd boss prepares for tough test
body: Michael Carrick has only had a few days on the training pitch with his Manchester United players(Image: Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)
Michael Carrick has been dropped straight into a Manchester Derby, with Manchester City visiting Old Trafford on Saturday looking to spoil the party.

Carrick has not been afforded much time to implement his ideas since being appointed as interim head coach until the end of the season. But Manchester United fans will be hoping the fabled new manager bounce can kickstart their season against their rivals.

Pep Guardiola is on a roll and will surely spoil Michael Carrick’s big day. It is set up for a huge occasion and an opportunity for Manchester United’s latest manager. But it is hard to see United boss Carrick and his merry band stopping Manchester City when they get on a roll.

It will definitely be a huge test for City’s resolve because United’s move to appoint their former player will give Old Trafford one hell of a lift and genuine hope of a place in next season’s Champions League places. There will be a buzz about United’s first line-up because it feels as if Carrick may be able to take the shackles off and be more attacking and entertaining than under Ruben Amorim.

But City boss Guardiola needs the wins and, after dropping points lately and defensive frailties, they looked to be back in an ominous groove at Newcastle in the Carabao Cup in midweek. City need to get going in this title race - and I think they will.
Prediction: Man Utd 1-2 Man City
Pep Guardiola will face off with Micahel Carrick this weekend(Image: Getty Images)

It will take a fair old new-manager bounce for United to get one over on Pep Guardiola’s side but this will be no procession for City. United will not only get a lift from the personable Michael Carrick, they will get a surge of adrenaline from the returning Amad and Bryan Mbeumo.

Despite a clean sheet at Newcastle in midweek, this City team is vulnerable to the counter attack and Carrick’s squad has plenty of attacking threat, if not clinical firepower. Amad might not start but Carrick will surely let Mbeumo loose and United can get at City in wide attacking areas.

There will be goals in this contest for the home team - it will just be the age-old question of whether they can stop the visitors scoring more. And against a City team that is unbeaten in 13 matches, that will be a big ask. The likes of Antoine Semenyo and Rayan Cherki look in prime form, to the extent where Phil Foden is not a guaranteed starter at Old Trafford. Considering his excellence in the first half of the season, that is frightening.

It will not be cagey, it will not be pedestrian. For the neutral, it should be a great watch. And not for the first time this season, United could play their part in an entertaining, high-scoring draw.
Prediction: Man Utd 3-3 Man City
Antoine Semenyo has hit the ground running since making his move to Manchester City(Image: (Photo by Alex Livesey - Danehouse/Getty Images))

There's naturally a new energy around United with Carrick in the building, but I can't see it being enough to get any joy out of the derby this weekend. The Red Devils' two results under Darren Fletcher highlight just how much work needs to be done.

And that isn't being pulled off across three days at Carrington. It will take time. Carrick may have a slight advantage in knowing Guardiola and City may struggle to assess what his team may or may not do given this is his first outing.

But those from the blue half remain in title contention and underlined their quality with a win at Newcastle during the week. They know they can ill-afford anymore draws if they're to catch Arsenal and Antoine Semenyo seems to have given them a new energy. I can't see anything other than a City win.
Prediction: Man Utd 0-2 Man City

Call it new-manager bounce or sheer determination not to lose the derby - and seriously damage City’s title challenge - but Michael Carrick’s side can get a point at Old Trafford. Manchester United have had a woeful few seasons and last few weeks. But their record against Pep Guardiola’s team has been better, including the FA Cup final win and two draws last season.

Expect more tactical flexibility from Carrick and another fresh start from his players. Benjamin Sesko has finally found his scoring boots and City’s depleted defence does concede goals. It is time the front trident with Bryan Mbuemo and Matheus Cunha fires together.

Stopping Erling Haaland at the other end is the big challenge but the Norwegian has only scored one in six. He does have five goals and three assists in three matches against Man Utd. It is will be fast and furious and a good result for Arsenal
Prediction: Man Utd 1-1 Man City
Amad and Bryan Mbeumo are back for Manchester United(Image: Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)

The romantics in red will believe Manchester United can produce a shock win. Michael Carrick will be taking charge of his first game, is a popular figure in the dressing room, while United will have home backing behind them.
And United have pulled off some unexpected derby wins before. But the realists will know there is more chance of Manchester City emerging triumphant.

The bottom line is that United have been dreadful in recent weeks, while City, despite having some injuries to contend with, have the better players in all departments. Most notably in attack, where United are missing Bryan Mbeumo and relying on the unpredictable Benjamin Sesko for goals, while City have a certain Erling Haaland leading the line. Haaland will be desperate to take down his neighbours.
Prediction: Man Utd 0-2 Man City
I expect there will be a new manager bounce off the pitch at least with the atmosphere at Old Trafford stepping up a notch for the visit of City.

Michael Carrick is a bona-fide United legend and will have the immediate backing of the Stretford End. But the fact remains United aren't very good and City are. Even with a couple of injury issues I expect them to have too much for United. Antoine Semenyo has had an immediate impact and I fancy him to have a big say here too.

Erling Haaland has been quiet by his standards in the last few weeks but this is exactly the kind of game that gets his juices pumping. United to come out of the blocks quickly, maybe even take the lead. But City's quality to shine through in the end.
Prediction: Man Utd 1-3 Man City
Erling Haaland is an obvious threat for Manchester City(Image: Getty Images)

After beating him in the race to become the latest holder of the poisoned chalice, Carrick will need to take a leaf out of Ole Gunnar Solskjaer’s book. Incredibly, the Norwegian had a winning Premier League record vs Guardiola as United boss, beating him three times, drawing once and losing twice in their six meetings.

United will be hoping for the similar sort of bounce they enjoyed under Solskjaer, unfortunately for Carrick the team still has huge limitations. The return of Mbeumo and Amad will help, but as Darren Fletcher showed, vibes and talk of the ‘United Way’ isn’t enough for this group of players.
And with Semenyo in their ranks, City feel like they could go on a real roll now. I fancy them to keep United at arms’ length in a comfortable away win.

headline: Man United vs Man City Premier League preview, team news and prediction
body: Michael Carrick will lead United at Old Trafford in the Manchester Derby this weekend(Image: Getty Images)
Manchester United welcome Manchester City to Old Trafford this weekend for the highly anticipated Manchester derby, with Michael Carrick stepping in for his second stint as interim manager.

Carrick faces a daunting start to his tenure, with back-to-back fixtures against local rivals City and, the following week, league leaders Arsenal. United’s recent league form has been underwhelming, managing just three wins in their last ten matches and currently enduring a four-game winless streak across all competitions, following a recent defeat to Brighton & Hove Albion. The timing of Carrick’s appointment could prove pivotal, as the club’s decision to wait until this week has left him with minimal time to implement changes on the training ground.

Despite ranking among the league’s top scorers with 36 goals, United have struggled defensively, registering only two clean sheets all season—a worrying statistic as they prepare to face a Manchester City side boasting the Premier League’s most prolific attack, with 45 goals to their name.

City enter the derby as favourites to complete the league double over their rivals. Pep Guardiola’s side are in outstanding form, unbeaten in their last 13 matches following a win at St. James’ Park. In the league, City have not lost since their 2-1 defeat at Newcastle United in November, winning six and drawing three of their last nine games. The Citizens have also claimed victory in three of the last six league encounters between the two teams.

City will be confident heading into the clash, especially given the uncertainty surrounding Carrick’s impact in his first game back in charge. With United’s defensive frailties and City missing key defenders Ruben Dias and Josko Gvardiol, an open, high-scoring affair could be on the cards.

Manchester United continue to be without Noussair Mazraoui, who is away at the Africa Cup of Nations, and defender Matthijs de Ligt, sidelined with a back injury. Teenage forward Shea Lacey is also unavailable due to suspension following his late red card in last weekend’s FA Cup loss to Brighton.

However, manager Michael Carrick will have attacking options Bryan Mbeumo and Amad Diallo back at his disposal after both were eliminated from AFCON. Mbeumo, United’s top scorer this season with seven goals, is likely to start on the right wing.

Carrick, expected to stick with a back four, faces some selection decisions—particularly at left-back, where he must choose between Luke Shaw and Patrick Dorgu. In midfield, Kobbie Mainoo will be hoping to make his first Premier League start of the season, competing with Manuel Ugarte and Mason Mount for a place in the lineup.

On the Manchester City side, Josko Gvardiol (tibial fracture), Mateo Kovacic (ankle/heel), John Stones (thigh), Ruben Dias, Oscar Bobb (both hamstring), and Savinho (unspecified) are all out with injuries. Omar Marmoush remains on international duty with Egypt at AFCON.

Antoine Semenyo, who has scored three goals in his last four appearances against United, is a strong candidate to start on either wing for City. Playmaker Rayan Cherki, who found the net in midweek, could be recalled to the starting lineup, potentially at the expense of Jeremy Doku.

At the back, Max Alleyne has impressed since returning from his loan at Watford, winning 92% of his duels for City this season (12 out of 13), including all six aerial contests. The 20-year-old could be rewarded with another start at centre-back alongside Abdukodir Khusanov.

body: Michael Carrick's wife was the subject of some personal criticism from Roy Keane(Image: OLI SCARFF/AFP via Getty Images)

Manchester United head coach Michael Carrick said he wasn't bothered by Roy Keane's criticism of his wife and insisted he can shrug off the opinions of former teammates at Old Trafford. Keane used his role on The Overlap podcast to take a potshot at Carrick's wife, saying she had a "big mouth" in comments that seemed to recall Lisa's response to some criticism from Keane to her husband back in the 2013/14 season.

Carrick gave the TV interview after United lost 2-0 to Olympiakos in the first leg of a Champions League last-16 tie and in his role as a pundit, Keane turned his ire on the midfielder who inherited his No.16 shirt at United. “That interview was just like the performance: flat. He should say a bit more, have a bit more urgency, even in the interview," said Keane.

Lisa took to social media to blast: "Roy Keane what a **** will say anything to provoke a reaction." That post was later deleted, but Keane clearly remembers it, judging by his dig this week. He added that Carrick's wife is "probably doing the team talk".

Carrick held his first press conference since being appointed as head coach until the end of the season and was asked about the personal nature of those comments, but insisted it wasn't an issue for him.

headline: MARSHALL: Manchester United got what they wanted in Michael Carrick's first press conference
body: Michael Carrick gave little away in his Manchester United press conference(Image: )

You could imagine the scene. Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox gathered around one of the TVs in Carrington's open-plan set-up, watching the latest Manchester United head coach speak to the media. It's been a moment of the week that the club's powerbrokers haven't exactly been looking forward to in recent weeks.

But if Ruben Amorim was the press conference equivalent of Bazball, capable of going on the attack at any of the deliveries he would face, then Carrick was the next man in when all that unravels. The equivalent of losing an Ashes series 4-1 and deciding you now need someone to show the straightest of straight bats.

That is exactly what Carrick did when the cameras rolled for the first press conference of his second spell in charge at Old Trafford. In November 2021, his pre-match press conferences were held on Zoom. In person, he would watch the ball carefully, then drop it safely at his feet.

You could say the end of the Amorim era was categorised by press conference broadsides, but they were simply more spectacular at the end. Throughout his reign, he would throw in grenades when speaking to the media. From criticisms of players to calling his squad "maybe the worst Manchester United team in history", he was a headline-making machine.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

United didn't want any more of that. Wilcox quickly decided he wanted someone who knew the club to take over for the rest of the season. Carrick was the coach with the biggest upside, the one whose potential remains unexplored, but he is also a safe pair of hands.
Across a little over four minutes and five questions while the cameras were rolling, the 44-year-old gave nothing away. Berrada and Wilcox would have been clinking glasses and exchanging high fives.

There were a couple of questions in there that could have made headlines: his conversations with the owners and Roy Keane's unnecessary criticism of his wife. Carrick negotiated them both safely. He offered almost no insight into what he had said to Sir Jim Ratcliffe and the Glazers and claimed he wasn't bothered by Keane's uncalled-for attack on Lisa.

Even the questions about football were dealt with to try to avoid creating a story. Success would simply be improving. Improve the players and the rest will take care of itself. He also said that Wilcox and Berrada had laid no expectations for the rest of the season.

Given United's ambitions clearly remain to qualify for Europe and that Darren Fletcher had laid down the Champions League as a challenge last Sunday, that seems unlikely. But Carrick's approach was to try and avoid heaping any unnecessary pressure on the squad.

Carrick may have hinted at his approach to media dealings in his first response. Asked how he had found his first few days back and what it was like to be sitting in the media chair, he said: "Two very different roles sat in this chair in front of you lot, it's very different to the role in coaching."

Ultimately, the club's former midfielder will be judged on results, but you can imagine his bosses will be happy if he avoids making any noise as well. After the chaos of the Amorim era, what they need is stability. If Carrick provides that on and off the pitch, then they will be delighted.

headline: MARSHALL: Michael Carrick opens up on Manchester United chat with Ratcliffe and Glazers - 'A few things'
body: Sir Jim Ratcliffe and the Glazers were at Carrington on Thursday(Image: 2025 Jean Catuffe)

Michael Carrick said he had had the chance to "share a few things" with Manchester United owners Avram and Joel Glazer and Sir Jim Ratcliffe after they held meetings at Carrington on Thursday. The club's ownership group held an executive committee meeting at United's training ground in a show of support to the new head coach, who was appointed until the end of the season earlier this week.

Carrick took his first training session on Wednesday and revealed he has had plenty of discussions with chief executive Omar Berrada and director of football Jason Wilcox, who has been watching sessions on the grass at Carrington. But the presence of Ratcliffe and the Glazer family gave him a chance to hold wider discussions and although the 44-year-old didn't go into details on what had been said, he did reveal the meetings were a chance to talk about the current situation at Old Trafford.
"I've spoken to Jason an awful lot and working closely with Jason and Omar as well over the last few days, we've spoken a lot, as you'd imagine," he said.

"The ownership group were in and around it, it was nice to see them and meet them yesterday and have a small chat with them, taking care of business in some ways. We were able to share a few things, so they wished us all the very best and it was good to see them."
United have made European football their target this season but Carrick was coy when asked what success looks like, saying only he wanted to see improvement from his team.

He also claimed that Wilcox and Berrada had put no expectations on him when handing him a contract for the rest of the season, despite Darren Fletcher insisting they could qualify for the Champions League.

"No, not in terms of it has to be this way or that way," he said of the expectations. "Like I said, we want to be near the top of the league, we want to be top of the league. That's pretty obvious to say, but we've got to take some small steps towards that and European football obviously would be a step forward and we've got to keep pushing."

Asked what success looks like for him, Carrick said: "I think improvement, certainly improvement and helping improve individuals. A big part of what I really enjoy is improving individuals, and in the end, if you improve the individuals, you create a better team.

"Certainly working with the players and improving them with that. There's an element of performance, there's an element of improvement and there's an element of doing what it takes to win in certain ways and certain occasions. So certainly higher up the league we finish, we want to keep pushing and finishing higher up as we possibly can and we'll see where that takes us."

Gary Neville said Manchester United cannot consider keeping Michael Carrick as head coach beyond the end of the season.

headline: Michael Carrick told 'you can't not play him' as demand made of new Man United boss
body: Michael Carrick could have no choice but to call on youth during his caretaker spell(Image: Ash Donelon/Manchester United via Getty Images)

Former Manchester United man Clayton Blackmore believes academy talent Shea Lacey has to be given more opportunities in the first team. This comes following reports the club's board have no intention to invest in new signings this month.

Lacey, 18, earned his senior debut against Aston Villa last month and has shown promise in his brief cameos. However, the teenager endured a moment to forget during the recent 2-1 defeat at home to Brighton in the FA Cup when he was sent off for two yellow cards in quick succession.

Michael Carrick is under immense pressure to make the most of United's current crop after replacing Ruben Amorim at the helm. But if the club is cautious about spending in the transfer market, Blackmore believes a rising gem like Lacey could prove valuable in the coming months.

"I like the lad Lacey," he told MEN Sport, via Stake. "His family are Liverpool fans. He’s from Liverpool. He’s the only one in the family who supports United. So that’s got to be an edge for him. I’m looking forward to seeing him playing more.

"That’s the good thing [Darren] Fletcher has done. He’s brought him in and we were thinking, ‘Wow, where’s he been? Why are you not playing him?’ You can’t not play him because of his age. It’s like Sir Matt Busby said, 'If you’re good enough, you’re old enough.'"

Lacey, who will be suspended for Saturday's derby against Manchester City, was just 15 when he earned his debut for United's under-18s, and he's ahead of schedule again in making his mark for the first team. Despite the inevitable gloom following his dismissal against Brighton, he's already shown plenty for fans to get excited about.
Lacey has shown plenty of fight as a United first-team player, but his passion got him sent off in the recent FA Cup loss to Brighton (Image: Richard Sellers/Sportsphoto/Allstar via Getty Images)

If anything, there's even a silver lining to glean from his red card in the FA Cup. That being an intense desire to fight for the club cause, something other players have been accused of lacking all too often in recent years.

There's also the fact Lacey fronted up in response to the incident and wrote on social media: "I want to apologise to all of my teammates staff and the fans. I let everybody down tonight I shouldn’t let my emotions get the better of me I will do everything I can to make this right."

Those words demonstrate a sense of accountability way beyond his years, another trait that has sometimes been absent in the squad. And Blackmore, who made 241 appearances for United and won both the Premier League and FA Cup, likes what he's seen thus far, with Fletcher using his brief time in charge of the club to put Lacey on everyone's map.
Blackmore made 241 appearances for United, winning the FA Cup, one Premier League title and the European Cup Winners' Cup(Image: Matthew Ashton/AMA/Corbis via Getty Images)

The player faces a difficult battle for prominence in his preferred right wing role under Carrick. Bryan Mbeumo, who has returned to the squad following his Africa Cup of Nations commitments, is the clear choice in that position, with Amad behind him.

However, Lacey has also shown promise in more central positions and boasts a dangerous left foot. This was on display during the recent 2-2 draw against Burnley, where he unleashed a beautifully whipped effort from the edge of the box that cannoned off Martin Dubravka's crossbar.

Carrick may harbour desires that his academy will produce similarly special talents in central midfield or in the full-back areas if United are intent on not spending for the remainder of the season. But Lacey has displayed enough in recent weeks to suggest he's got what it takes to make a first-team impact in the months to come.

headline: Nine players set to miss Man United vs Man City
body: Manchester United host Manchester City at Old Trafford in the second Manchester derby of the Premier League campaign.

Much attention has been on Michael Carrick, who was appointed United's interim boss until the end of the season. He comes into the fixture wishing to make the perfect start to life in charge of the club which he used to play for, but must do so without an entire squad to pick from.

Meanwhile, Pep Guardiola in the opposite dugout has just as much pressure to contend with knowing City have several injuries to deal with - both short and long term - amid this season's ongoing title race.
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page
FOLLOW OUR MAN CITY FB PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester City Facebook page

Starting with hosts United, they will be without Matthijs de Ligt due to a back injury. On Friday Carrick stated the defender's recovery has been "slower" than expected, but he should be back "some time soon."

United are without a second defender, Noussair Mazraoui, as he is still competing at this winter's Africa Cup of Nations. The 28-year-old is expected to feature in Sunday's final for tournament hosts Morocco against Senegal.
United recalled Toby Collyer from his West Brom loan earlier in January. He is completing his recovery and is not expected to be available until later this month.

Now onto City, who have the lion share of injuries between the two clubs heading into the Manchester derby. Guardiola will wait to include Nico Gonzalez in his squad after he missed Tuesday's Carabao Cup win over Newcastle United. "We’ll see this afternoon in training," said the City boss on Friday.
Ruben Dias picked up a hamstring injury against Chelsea in early January and was ruled out for four to six weeks by his manager. On Friday, Guardiola added the defender should be back "soon."
John Stones has been unable to play since early December due to a thigh injury. The Manchester derby comes too soon for him.

Josko Gvardiol will not only miss the trip to Old Trafford but for the majority of what remains of the 2025/26 campaign. This comes after the Croatian international required surgery on a tibial fracture earlier this month.

Omar Marmoush remains out of Guardiola's selection as he is still required to represent Egypt at AFCON. The attacker is expected to take part in Saturday's third-place play-off against Nigeria, after his country suffered a semi-final defeat to Senegal. After the weekend he will return to Manchester.
Guardiola confirmed Bobb remains unavailable ahead of the weekend after the 22-year-old picked up a hamstring injury last week.

headline: Man United manager targets available in 2026 after huge Oliver Glasner update
body: Oliver Glasner may have made himself available to take over as Manchester United manager this summer, upon making the revelation that he will leave Crystal Palace when his contract expires.

United are already looking ahead to next season and making sure they hire correctly when picking the club's next manager. Ruben Amorim was shown the door at the start of January and Michael Carrick will see through the remainder of the 2025/26 campaign before club chiefs reach a final, permanent solution in the summer.
FA Cup and Community Shield winner Glasner is one of several high-profile figures linked with Old Trafford, and now the German has made known his availability once the current season ends.
I've worked with Man United's dream signing – he's got exactly what they need
Wayne Rooney reveals his choice for next Man United manager as he makes Liverpool prediction

On Friday afternoon, Glasner dropped the bombshell that he will be leaving Crystal Palace at the end of his contract this summer.
"I told Steve (Parish) I’m looking for a new challenge," he announced. "It’s my feeling after everything. I told him in October it’s nothing to do with the transfer window.
"I hate if something is written that is not true it’s tough for me to respond. We have a great relationship and always talking what’s best for Palace."
This fits perfectly with the timing of United's appointment of their next permanent manager, though Glasner added: "I haven’t spoken to any other club.
"I told the players, promised them, I will give my best to get the points record. We will do everything to bring another trophy back to Selhurst Park."
Thomas Tuchel has the task of winning England their second-ever FIFA World Cup. Afterwards, his contract with the Football Association will expire.
It remains to be seen what path the former Chelsea boss will take, though last November he appeared to suggest he was pleased in his current surroundings.

"I’m very relaxed," he explained. "I was the one to push for a short contract, to streamline it and go to the World Cup, because I was not fully aware of the job and what is needed and how I would feel in the job.
"Nothing has changed. The focus is the World Cup and the federation knows that I’m happy. They play a big part in me feeling good and re-energised."

Another manager who is out of contract once the FIFA World Cup is over is Mauricio Pochettino. The former Tottenham and Chelsea manager will be making the big calls for one of the tournament's hosts, the US Men's National Team, with big expectations to carry.

If United were so impatient they could not wait for the Argentine until after the World Cup, reports suggest they would have to pay "one of the biggest financial compensation fees in football history."

Carlo Ancelotti took over as head coach of Brazil when he left Real Madrid in May of last year, hoping the 66-year-old would bring them an abundance of glory as he did for the Spanish giants, Chelsea, AC Milan, Bayern Munich, and Paris Saint-Germain over the years.
United may have the same idea this summer and will be pleased to know the Italian's contract with the Brazilian Football Confederation (CBF) expires after the FIFA World Cup this summer.

"Not just from my side. I am talking about the club, too. The club has a project, an idea and an ambition.

In his two seasons in England so far his team have finished 13th and ninth, breaking his own points record with the latter.

Whilst he is linked with spearheading United's next project, there is a sense he could become the next French National Team boss after this summer's World Cup.
Like Zidane, former Barcelona hero Xavi progressed from playing to management and won the club the La Liga title from the dugout in 2022/23. One year later, he departed.

headline: MARSHALL: Michael Carrick plans, chance for youngsters and transfers - Man United questions answered
body: There are plenty of questions to answer at Manchester United(Image: )

A lot can change in a week and the last time we answered your Manchester United questions it looked like Ole Gunnar Solskjaer would be the man in the Old Trafford dugout for this weekend's Manchester derby. Instead, Michael Carrick is the man who will aim to oversee a win against United's city rivals.

The former Middlesbrough boss impressed Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox during the interview process and has been handed the reins until the end of the season. Everyone wants to know what we can expect to see from the new man in charge and who the winners and losers will be from his appointment, and we'll look to answer some of those questions in this week's Q&A.
We run weekly question and answer sessions so click here to submit your questions and we'll answer them next week. Here are the answers to some of this week's questions:
What is the plan of the board of directors to bring the glory days back to United?

A nice, easy one to start with. The board of directors have essentially given control of football matters to Omar Berrada and Jason Wilcox. So their plan is for Berrada and Wilcox to get things right. As for the plan of Berrada and Wilcox, well, who knows?
FOLLOW OUR MAN UNITED FACEBOOK PAGE! Latest news and analysis via the MEN’s Manchester United Facebook page

This isn't hindsight; I have consistently said that the appointment of Amorim was a strange one for a club looking to move away from a dominant head coach/manager. Amorim has one of the most distinctive playing systems in Europe and the only way that can work is by signing him specialists.

The one positive recently has been recruitment, which was better in the summer. But the decision on who to appoint next is vital and could make or break this Ineos regime. Berrada has championed Project 150, which is a desire to win the league in the club's 150th anniversary season in 2027/28. Right now those look like hollow words and bland executive speak.

The plan right now has to be get the right head coach. Do that and things might fall into place, but there is no escaping the fact that the structure of ownership and the combination of the Glazers and Sir Jim Ratcliffe make success a challenge for this club at the moment.
What is Carrick's formation?
He was a 4-2-3-1 man at Middlesbrough and I would imagine we will see that again. That was the system Ole Gunnar Solskjaer played at United and Carrick kept it during his three games in charge.

That kind of shape can easily become a 4-3-3 if one of the two sitting midfielders moves forward, but I imagine it will be more of a cautious set-up for now, given the first two games are against Manchester City and Arsenal.
Give Lacey a chance - Cunha and Dalot are not worth United shirts.

Lacey has started to get a chance of late and I think he will stay in and around the first-team set-up. His problem now is Amad and Bryan Mbeumo are back and after this weekend (when Lacey is suspended) there are only 16 games left of the season. As talented as Lacey is, I don't think anyone can suggest he should be starting games ahead of Amad or Mbeumo right now.

Cunha has had a slow start to his Old Trafford career. I thought there were positive signs in mid-December but he's gone off the boil again. With Amad and Mbeumo away, he should have grabbed this team by the scruff of the neck, but he's gone back to playing with the handbrake on. I wouldn't be giving up on him any time soon, though. We have seen there is a very good Premier League player in there.
Let's get Xabi Alonso - he's a man with vision and a winning mentality.

Alonso feels like a difficult appointment, given his Liverpool connections, but I do think he would be a very good one. I wouldn't hold what happened at Real Madrid against him; that place chews up and spits out coaches and Alonso's desire to actually try and change the culture should be seen as a positive, if anything.

But there is a good chance Alonso is next in line at Anfield and he would have to ask himself if he was willing to blow up the chance of ever coaching Liverpool by moving to United. I'm not sure I can see it.
Why is Harry Maguire not starting as well as Shea Lacey and Kobbie Mainoo?

Maguire has just returned from injury and needs to get back to full fitness. I would have him in central defence alongside Martinez at the moment, but he had two months out and needs to make sure he is fully recovered.

I don't think there has been an obvious time to start Lacey and with all the attacking players now back, I don't think he gets a start anytime soon. His development is going along just fine if he stays around the first-team squad.
As for Mainoo, I think we all know why he wasn't starting under Amorim. He just didn't trust the 20-year-old in his midfield. I'd be amazed if Carrick didn't hand him more opportunities.
Why don't the club send Diogo Dalot out on loan?
Not sure I see any merit in this, to be honest. Dalot is 26, there is no point sending him on loan to develop and he is the first-choice right-back and a member of the leadership group.

He's had a difficult season and the criticism of him from supporters has been noticeably louder this year. I'm not sure he's the long-term answer at right-back but there is no replacement ready to go either. Even if Noussair Mazraoui takes that place next week, Dalot would be needed as back-up.
There is probably an argument to sign a right-back in the summer, although midfield has to be the priority. It feels inevitable that Dalot will face more competition at some point.
